children.subject: Having taken Stat 134 is a huge help for CS70. It is definitely doable and will be easier with your experience but it would still require a fair amount of work

history.content:
It is definitely doable. Make sure you put in the work - go to office hours/hw parties, understand and internalize the material thoroughly. 134 will make the probability portion of 70 more comfortable for you (because of your familiarity with the concepts) but beware that the style of probability questions on 70 tests are more tricky as opposed to conventional math-y problems you might have encountered in 134.

For motivation, I got the same grades as you in the above classes and still made it to the CS major with an A- in CS70. You can do it! :)

children.subject:
134 definitely helps with your understanding of probability portion in cs70. However, I definitely agree with the anon that 134's questions are kind of different from 70's questions. I thought I understood most concepts really well in 134 but then cs70 just came up with creative and sometimes tricky problems that are less conventional. With stat134, I could breeze through cs70 lectures and discussions. However, to do well on the test, you have to try as hard as other students who are just learning probability the first time around. Best way to prep is to do past exam questions and understand professor's probability homework questions and slides.

About 70% of materials covered in 134 will eventually come up in cs70. However, at some point, 134 gets obsessed with distributions and their manipulations. Hence, if you want to take them both concurrently then you need to spend time understanding concepts in 134 that are probably less relevant in cs70. It's your call, it was super fun for me though. Make sure you take the adjunct class offered by the SLC with 134 if you decide to take it.
how much does doing stat 134 help in cs 70?
Do you have a link/know where to find that lecture by Sahai?

https://coursecapture.berkeley.edu/compsci-70 has all previous iterations that were webcasted. Sahai expects you to have read the notes first and discuss materials outside of notes while Vazirani goes over the notes pretty well too.

there is also the data science major! anyway, I got the exact same grade you got for 61ab. I almost gave up in the beginning because I thought I was never smart enough to do CS. However, I decided to take 134 and 70 together this semester and got a good grade in 134 and an A- in 70, just enough to declare CS (actually I spent way too much time in 134 and not enough in 70). Its totally possible to do well in 70. Start reading 70 notes right now. Review notes before lectures because IMO its impossible to understand cs70 lectures well without any prep. I watched Sahai's old webcasts to get more intuitions behind certain topics such as stable marriage(one of his first few lectures was really motivational and it was where he gave a slide about how much time a well-rested, undistracted cs70 student should spend on the course —about 3~4 hours daily, which I followed closely in the beginning and was reflected in my high mt1 score). Be active on piazza and participate in discussions, I suffered from inferiority complex in 61ab since I did not have coding experience, but you just learn so much better when you participate and interact with the TA(go to a 2nd day afternoon small section). Go to office hour and lastly, take many practice tests! (I feel like doing past exams have the most return in Rao's cs70 course out of any other courses).

I cannot speak as to what major you should pursue, but it would definitely be doable to get an A- in 70! In fact, I did average for both the midterms but was so confused and overwhelmed by the course material that I was convinced I would fail the final. After having a one-on-one with one of the TAs, I was able to pull myself together and do well enough on the final to get an A- in the class. 

In terms of doing well in 70, I concur with the followup above me- definitely read the notes and make sure you understand everything. The notes are very dense and having only a vague understanding of one line in a proof can fool you into thinking that you understand a concept. When the semester starts, I highly suggest doing and understanding the homework, as questions from the exams often draw from the homeworks. Lastly, if you ever feel lost/ overwhelmed, definitely reach out to a TA! It was not until I spoke to a TA that I felt more equipped to tackle the course and I certainly wish that I had done so sooner. Hopefully all the followups in this thread will help you out though :)
Thank you guys so much, this was encouraging and just what I needed to hear! -OP

history.content:
I'm a sophomore, and I did so poorly in a class for my backup major (statistics) that my only option right now is to declare CS. I got a B in 61a, B+ in 61b, and B in Stat 134 (don't remember much from that though).

I know it'll be hard, but would it be a smart decision to drop stats entirely and focus on 70 if there's a chance I can't declare? I don't have much "mathematical maturity", but I'm willing to self-study for the next few weeks and I quit my job recently so I'll have more time to spend on this. 

My other option is to take math 1a with my last prereq to boost my gpa for statistics. I'd much prefer a CS major, but if that's not a risk worth taking then I'll take the stats route.

Any input would be greatly appreciated, because I'm having an enrollment crisis right now. Thanks so much!
history.subject: How doable is it to get an A- in CS70?
